{{Noble House infobox | name=House of Fëanor | image = Amanyar - Fëanor device.png | caption= | othernames=''Nos Fëanor'' ([[Noldorin|N]])
The Dispossessed | founder=[[Fëanor]] | location=[[Tirion]], [[Formenos]], [[East Beleriand]], [[Eregion]] | affiliation=[[Gwaith-i-Mírdain]], [[House of Finwë]], [[Union of Maedhros]] | rivalry= | destroyed={{SA|1697}}It is possible that [[Fëanor|Fëanor's]] second son [[Maglor]] survived beyond this date. He lived past the end of the [[First Age]], wandering the shores of Middle-earth lamenting his lost [[Silmaril]]. It's at least conceivable that he lived on into the [[Second Age]] and beyond, but his fate is unknown. | language=[[Fëanorian dialect]] ([[Exilic Quenya]])
[[Sindarin]] | members=[[Sons of Fëanor]], [[Celebrimbor]] | race=[[Noldor]] | distinctions= | height= | hair=Black, red | skin= | clothing= | weapons=Sword | heirlooms=[[Silmarils]] | gallery=the House of Fëanor }} {{quote|On the House of Fëanor the wrath of the Valar lieth from the West unto the uttermost East, and upon all that will follow them it shall be laid also.|[[Doom of Mandos]]}} The '''House of Fëanor''' were the cursed descendants and followers of [[Fëanor]], the eldest son of [[Finwë]] and his spouse [[Míriel]]. ==History== [[File:Angel Falto - Feanor & Sons.jpg|left|thumb|''Feanor & Sons'' by [[:Category:Images by Angel Falto|Angel Falto]]]] Fëanor was one of the greatest, and certainly the most skilled,{{S|6}} of the [[Noldor]], but his burning anger at the loss of his [[Silmarils]] led him to commit acts that would greatly diminish the influence of his house among his people. As the heir of Finwë, his descendants (specifically [[Maedhros]], his eldest son) should have inherited the [[King of the Noldor|Kingship of the Noldor]], but because of Fëanor's rash acts, the lordship of the Noldor passed to his brothers: [[Finarfin]] in [[Aman]],{{S|Flight}} and [[Fingolfin]] in [[Middle-earth]].{{S|Return}} For this reason, and for the loss of the Silmarils, the members of the House of Fëanor are referred to as the ''Dispossessed''. The history of the House was a woeful one, and most of its members met an early end. Fëanor and six of his seven sons perished before the end of the First Age. His second son [[Maglor]] survived beyond the [[War of Wrath]], wandering the shores of Middle-earth, but his fate is unknown.{{S|24}} The last of the House was Fëanor's grandson [[Celebrimbor]], the son of [[Curufin]],{{PM|XNotes}}, Note 7, pp. 317-9 who had a great part in the making of the [[Rings of Power]], and was tortured to death by [[Sauron]] during the [[Second Age]].{{UT|Concerning}} ==Genealogy== {{familytree/start}} {{familytree| MHT | | MIR |y| FIN | | | | | | | | | | | | | |MHT=[[Mahtan]]

''d. {{SA|1697}}''}} {{familytree/end}} ==Other names== In the [[The Etymologies|''Etymologies'']], the [[Noldorin]] name of the House of Fëanor was '''''Nos Fëanor''''' (cf. ''[[nossë#Quenya|nosse]]'').{{VT|46a}}, p. 6 [[Christopher Tolkien]] used the term "'''[[Fëanorians]]'''" for the followers of Fëanor many times in his notes and comments along ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]'', probably just for practical reasons.{{HM|IX}}, pp. 158-159 It is used like this by the [[fandom]]. In the fourth stanza of the final form of the ''[[Eärendillinwë]]'', Tolkien uses the word '''Fëanorians''', though it is unclear if the term refers to the followers of Fëanor or the [[Sons of Fëanor]].{{TI|V}}, pp. 102, 104 Tolkien also uses the word '''Fëanorian''', when discussing linguistic matters of Old [[Sindarin]], to refer to the people of the House of Fëanor.{{PE|17}}, pg. 131 {{references|notes}} [[Category:Elven noble houses]] [[Category:House of Fëanor| ]] [[fi:Fëanorin huone]]
